title: Michael van Gerwen explains why ‘darts needs people like Gerwyn Price’
text:
Gerwyn Price has earned the respect of Michael van Gerwen (Picture: Getty Images)

Michael van Gerwen has high praise for Gerwyn Price, saying that ‘darts needs people like him’ after their epic semi-final clash at the Champions League on Sunday night.

The pair produced a thrilling contest in Leicester, with Van Gerwen edging out the Welshman 11-10 to reach the final, which he went on to win by the same scoreline against Peter Wright.

MVG has an entirely one-sided record against Price, winning 17 of the 18 matches they have played, with the other ending in a draw in the Premier League.

However, the Dutchman has nothing but kind words for the world number five, describing it as a ‘privilege to play against him.’

‘Gerwyn Price is an underestimated player,’ the world champion told Live Darts. ‘The crowd is never on his side, but with his ability and how much power he puts into a game, it’s phenomenal, to be fair.

‘It’s a privilege to play against him because darts needs people like him who gives it a go. We don’t like boring players, we want some characters in the game.’

Van Gerwen and Price have a friendly rivalry (Picture: Getty Images)

Price took the demoralising loss on the chin as he continues his search for a first victory over the world number one.

The Iceman is getting extremely close, with his last four games against MVG ending in a one-leg victory for the Dutchman and that one draw in the Premier League.

The 34-year-old admits that the pressure got to him in the deciding leg on Sunday, but is already relishing another crack at the three-time world champion.

‘I thought I played pretty well, I dominated most of that game, Michael played really well, we both did,’ Price told the BBC after the narrow loss.

‘Stages in that game I thought I was in control but same as always happens, I messed up that last leg, I probably should have beat him, but that last leg, my arse went again.

‘I’m under pressure in that last leg, Michael’s been there so many times, I’m gutted I lost but there’s plenty more to come.’

Both men return to action at the European Championship which begins on Thursday in Gottingen.
